Scheme 1 SCR reaction mechanism on Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalyst. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 NO x conversion (a,b) and N2 selectivity (c) over Mn/TiO2 catalysts and Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts with different Sm loadings as a function of temperature. Reaction conditions: 500 ppm of NO, 500 ppm of NH3, 5 % of O2, and N2 as balance, GHSV =80,000 h−1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 SEM images and element mappings of 20 Mn/TiO2 (A) and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 (B) catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts with different Sm contents. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Raman spectra of Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts with different Sm contents. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Ti 2p, Sm 3d, Mn 2p and O1 s XPS spectrum of the Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 NH3-TPD profiles of Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 H2-TPR profiles of Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 In situ DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption at 50 °C and desorption from 50 to 300 °C over 20 Mn/TiO2 (a) and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 (b) catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 In situ DRIFT spectra recorded for 20 Mn/TiO2 (a) and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 (b) catalysts exposure to 500 ppm of NH3/N2 at different times after adsorption of 500 ppm of NO + 5 % O2/N2 at 120 °C and purging with N2 for 1 h. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 In situ DRIFT spectra recorded for 20 Mn/TiO2 (a) and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 (b) catalysts exposure to 500 ppm of NO + 5 % O2/N2 at different times after adsorption of 500 ppm of NH3/N2 at 120 °C and purging with N2 for 1 h. Graphical abstract A series of Sm modified Mn/TiO2 catalysts were proposed for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 and their catalytic activity was evaluated at low temperature. The effect of Sm on the catalytic activity of Mn-Sm/TiO2 was comprehensively studied using XRD, low-temperature N2 adsorption, XPS, NH3-TPD and H2-TPR. The results showed that the 20Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst, prepared by ultrasonic impregnation, exhibited NO x conversion of higher than 80 % at the temperature range of 110–250 °C with a gas hourly space velocity of 80,000 h−1. The weak Lewis acid site and redox ability may be crucial properties for catalytic performance as a result of the increase of Mn4+ and surface chemisorption oxygen as well as weak acid sites due to the enhanced interaction among Mn, Sm and Ti after addition of Sm. The in situ DRIFTS experiments were conducted to investigate the adsorption of NH3 and NO with their surface reaction. The results revealed that the SCR reactions on the surface of Mn/TiO2 catalyst follow both Langmuir-Hinshelwood and Eley-Rideal mechanism and bridging nitrate is the important intermediate. While, that on surface of 20Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst comply with only Eley-Rideal mechanism, as the introduction of Sm changes the reaction path by inhibiting the adsorption of NO in the presence of NH3. Besides, SCR reaction rate over 20Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst is fast as a result of large amount of -NH2 species formed on the surface of 20Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst for the breaking of NH bonds become easier over the Sm modified catalyst, which is beneficial for SCR activity of 20Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst at low temperature. The TG-DSC-MS results revealed that the addition of Sm reduce the sulfation of Mn/TiO2 catalyst. Keywords Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalyst Low-temperature NH3-SCR SCR mechanism SO2 tolerance 1 Introduction Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of nitrogen oxides with ammonia over V2O5−WO3/TiO2 catalysts is the most widely established technology for control of NO x emissions from stationary sources such as incinerators and power plants [1]. The commercial SCR catalysts are placed upstream of electrostatic precipitator (ESP) as the commercial catalyst has high activity and selectivity at 300−400 °C [2]. However, these SCR catalysts would suffer from some problems in practical application, such as abrasion caused by high content of fly ash, deactivation due to alkalis and SO2, and high conversion of SO2 to SO3 at high temperature. To avoid these problems, one solution proposed is to place the SCR unit downstream of air preheater and ESP, even after flue gas desulfurization (FGD). However, the temperature of flue gas is significantly decreased after passing through the ESP and desulfurizer. Besides, the temperature of flue gas in other industries, such as metallurgy, cement, glass and waste incineration, is also below 300 °C. Therefore, developing novel SCR catalysts with high activity at low temperature has attracted great interest and currently emerging. Over the past decade, many researches [3–13] have been conducted to develop low-temperature SCR catalysts in which transition metal oxides catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activities. Peña et al. [12] investigated the low-temperature catalytic activities over oxides of the first row transition metal supported on anatase TiO2. The results indicated that Mn-based catalysts have the highest catalytic activities due to presence of Lewis acidity, redox properties, and higher surface concentration. Furthermore, Smirniotis et al. [14] compared low-temparature SCR activities of MnO2 deposited on various commercial supports such as TiO2, γ-Al2O3, and SiO2 to understand the effect of supports on SCR activity. TiO2-supported MnO2 catalysts exhibited higher SCR activity than SiO2- or Al2O3-supported MnO2 catalysts. However, SCR of NO over MnO x /TiO2 catalysts is prone to generate N2O as a byproduct. Besides, the MnO x /TiO2 catalysts still suffer from deactivation due to the presence of SO2 in treated flus gas. Wu et al. [15,16] found that the catalytic activity and resistance to SO2 were significantly promoted for Ce modified Mn/TiO2 catalyst because chemisorbed oxygen and acidity was increased and the formation of sulfate was inhibited after Ce doping. These results indicated that SCR activity of modified Mn/TiO2 catalyst could be significantly promoted. To further increase the catalytic performance at lower temperature, many research work have been carried out for the modified Mn/TiO2 catalysts. Shen et al. [11] found that the low-temperature SCR activities and H2O/SO2 tolerance of Fe-doped Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts were improved due to the increase of dispersion and oxidation state of surface metal oxides as well as surface oxygen concentrations after iron doping. Jiang et al. [17] investigated Co modified MnO2 catalyst and found that this catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity in the presence of SO2 and H2O. Thirupathi et al. [10,18,19] used Co and Ni to modify the Mn/TiO2 catalyst and found that the SCR activities of modified catalysts were all promoted as a result of the increase in reducibility and active MnO2 phase. Gu et al. [20] explored SCR activities over Ca doped MnO x /TiO2 catalyst synthesized through sol-gel method and the results showed that the catalytic activities have been greatly improved. Putluru et al. [6] compared the low-temperature SCR activities of Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Fe/TiO2 catalysts and results displayed that Mn-Fe/TiO2 catalysts showed better catalytic activity due to the promotion of physicochemical property of Mn-Fe/TiO2 catalyst after Fe doping. Zhao et al. [21] evaluated SCR activities of Nb modified Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst and found that Nb doping improved the low-temperature activity and N2 selectivity. Based on Mn/TiO2 catalyst, introduction of another element significantly improves the catalytic activity through promoting the physicochemical property of the catalysts, which is beneficial for NH3-SCR at low temperature. Among these promoters, rare earth metals are considered as effective candidates for elevating catalytic activity as they promote metal dispersion, increase the thermal stability and efficiently store and release oxygen [22]. Ce is considered as an excellent promoter for improving low-temperature catalytic activity of Mn-based SCR catalysts because it can easily store and release oxygen via redox shift [23]. A novel Ho modified Fe-Mn/TiO2 catalysts were proposed by Zhu et al. [3] for low-temperature SCR of NO x and the doped Ho enhanced the catalytic performance and resistance to SO2 and H2O. Huang et al. [24] reported that the doping of different rare earth elements (Nd, Er and Y) can promote the low-temperature SCR catalytic activity of Mn/TiO2 catalyst. In recent years, it was reported that the presence of Sm remarkably improve the low-temperature catalytic activity and prohibit oxidation of SO2 to SO3 [25–27]. Therefore, the Sm modified Mn/TiO2 catalyst was proposed for low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO, since it is expected that interaction among Mn, Sm and Ti improves the physicochemical property. Furthermore, the effect of Sm on the surface physicochemical properties of Mn-based catalysts are different and the research results on the adsorption properties of reactant and reaction mechanism over Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalyst are inconsistent. In addition, the effect of Sm on the resistance to SO2 and H2O needs additional explorations. In the present work, a series of Sm modified Mn/TiO2 catalysts for low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO x have been developed. The physicochemical properties related to acidity and redox property of the Mn-Sm/TiO2 were systematically investigated using XRD, low-temperature N2 adsorption, XPS, NH3-TPD and H2-TPR. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was used to analyze the surface adsorbed species of reactants and the surface reactions on the catalysts. The role of Sm was evaluated and the SCR reaction mechanism over Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalyst was proposed based on the above experiments and analysis. The reaction mechanism is different from that observed for Mn/Ti catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts were prepared by ultrasonic impregnation method to improve the surface dispersion of active metal cation. To achieve this, the required amount of Mn(NO3)2 and Sm(NO3)3·6H2O was added to a 100 ml beaker containing 4 g of TiO2 (P25, Degussa) in 50 ml of deionized water. The beaker was then dipped in an ultrasonic generator (25 kHz and 400 W) and the ultrasonic treatment was performed at 60 °C for 8 h. The excess water was then slowly evaporated and the residues obtained were first dried at 110 °C for 12 h followed by calcination at 500 °C for 5 h under air condition. The obtained materials were ground and sieved to obtain homogeneous powder before activity testing. The catalysts were denoted as xMn-ySm/TiO2, where x represents the mass ratio of Mn/Ti and y refers to the mass ratio of Sm/Ti. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The morphologies of the catalysts were observed by ZEISS Sigma 300 scanning electron microscope (SEM) and the element distribution of the catalysts was detected by Oxford X-Max energy dispersive spectroscope (EDS). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on the X'pert PRO (PANalytical, Holland) using a Cu Kα radiation to determine the crystal phase structure of the samples. The applied voltage and current were 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively. The XRD spectra were recorded from 20 to 80° (2θ) at a rate of 0.013°/s. The phase composition was identified using ICDD cards (International Centre for Diffraction Data). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of the catalysts were measured by physical adsorption of N2 at −196 °C using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Laser Raman spectra of catalysts were examined on DXR2 Raman Microscope. Raman spectra were measured at room temperature using a 532 nm laser with a power of 0.5 mW. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained on Axis Ultra DLD-600W spectrometer (Kratos) at room temperature using monochromatic Al Kα radiation. Binding energies were corrected with reference to the C 1s value of 284.8 eV. The Mn 2p and O 1s peaks were deconvoluted with a Shirley background and a Gaussian-Lorentzian ratio of 80/20. The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was conducted on a Micromeritics ChemiSorb 2720 instrument with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In a typical TPD experiment, 100 mg of sample was placed in a U-type quartz tube and pretreated in helium flow (30 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h. Subsequent, the sample was cooled to 50 °C and saturated with NH3 (3 % in He) at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. After NH3 adsorption, the sample was purged with helium for 1 h to remove physisorbed NH3. Once a stable baseline has been achieved, the TPD operation was carried out by heating the sample from 50 to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and the TCD signals was recorded. The temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR) was conducted on a Micromeritics ChemiSorb 2720 instrument with a TCD. Prior to the analysis, approximately 100 mg of the catalysts were pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h in helium (30 mL/min) stream and then the sample was cooled to 100 °C. A stable baseline was obtained by TCD under H2 stream (10 % in Ar). The TPR runs were carried out by heating the sample from 100 to 500 °C with a linear rate (10 °C/min) in a flow of 10 % H2 in argon. The hydrogen consumption was recorded by TCD. The produced water was collected by cold trap during the TPR experiment. The in situ DRIFTS experiments were performed on Thermo Nicolet IS50 FTIR spectrometer with an MCT detector in the range of 4000−400 cm−1 with spectral resolution of 4 cm−1. The sample was placed in the IR cell with ZnSe windows and pretreated with N2 for 1 h at 300 °C to remove adsorbed impurities and then the sample was cooled to setting temperature. The background spectra was recorded at this temperature when the spectra was no longer change. Subsequent, the reaction gases were introduced into IR cell. The background was subtracted from in situ FTIR spectra recorded by the adsorption and reaction of the gases. Thermogravimetry (TG) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis of the catalysts were carried out on a PerkinElmer STA 8000 simultaneous thermal analyzer attached with a Hiden HPR20 mass spectrometer (MS) with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a flow of N2 to analyze sulfate species. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements The SCR performance measurements were carried out in a fixed-bed continuous flow quartz reactor with an internal diameter of 8 mm. 1 g of catalyst (40–60 mesh) was placed on sieve plate in the reactor. The simulated flue gas with a flow rate of 1 l/min normally consisted of 500 ppm of NO, 500 ppm of NH3, 5 vol.% of O2, 5 vol.% of H2O (when used), 100 ppm SO2 (when used) and N2 as balance. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was about 80,000 h−1. During the experiment, the temperature of catalyst was increased in steps from 80 to 300 °C, which was heated by a tubular furnace regulated by a temperature controller with a thermocouple inserted into the catalyst bed. The concentrations of NO, NO2, N2O, and NH3 in the reactor effluent were continually monitored by Gasmet DX4000 FT-IR flue gas analyzer and laser Raman spectrometer (Ruiyi LRGA-6000)and were recorded only after the reactions reached steady state at each temperature. The activity of the catalysts was given by NO x (NO and NO2) conversion (%) and the NO x conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated according to the following equations: N O x c o n v e r s i o n = [ NO x ] in - [ NO x ] out [ NO x ] in × 100 % N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y = [ NO x ] in + [ NH 3 ] in - [ NO x ] out - [ NH 3 ] out - 2 [ N 2 O] out [ NO x ] in + [ NH 3 ] in - [ NO x ] out - [ NH 3 ] out × 100 % where [NO x ]in and [NO x ]out are the concentrations of NO x at the inlet and outlet of reactor, respectively. [NH3]in and [NH3]out are the concentrations of NH3 at the inlet and outlet of reactor, respectively. [N2O]out is the concentration of N2O generated during the reaction process. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic behavior Initially, the catalytic performance of Mn/TiO2 catalysts were investigated to optimize the Mn content. Fig. 1 a shows the NO x conversion profiles of 10−35 Mn/TiO2 catalysts as a function of reaction temperatures. It can be observed that the Mn loading could indeed influence the SCR activities of Mn/TiO2 catalysts. The NO x conversions increased initially and then decreased with an increase in Mn loading of Mn/TiO2 catalysts at low temperatures. The best Mn/TiO2 catalyst was obtained with an optimum Mn loading of 20 %. The optimum 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst exhibited NO x conversion of only 52 % at 120 °C. The Mn/TiO2 catalysts do not obtain high NO conversions at low temperatures. Therefore, the Sm modified Mn/TiO2 catalysts are proposed to further optimize the low-temperature SCR catalyst. Fig. 1b shows the NO x conversion profiles of Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts with Sm loading of 3−20 wt%. The NO x conversions increased with gradual increase in Sm loading of Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts up to 10 wt%. The results clearly showed that introduction of Sm could significantly improve the low-temperature catalytic activity of Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalyst compared to that of Mn/TiO2 catalyst, especially at the temperature range of 80−150 °C. Furthermore, 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst exhibited the best low-temperature SCR activity, which exhibited more than 80 % NO x conversion at the temperature range of 110−250 °C with the GHSV of 80,000 h−1. The possible reason is that an optimal interaction between Mn and Sm species was achieved with this amount of Sm in Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalyst. Further increase in Sm content exceeding 15 wt% resulted in the decrease of NO x conversions, possibly due to coverage of Mn active sites by the presence of Sm and pore blocking. The NO x conversions of all the Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts gradually decline at above 200 °C. This is probably due to the overoxidation of NH3 at high temperature. In addition, the N2 selectivities of 20 Mn/TiO2 and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1c. The N2 selectivity of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst was enhanced within the whole temperature range, especially between 200−300 °C compared with that of 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst. The doping of Sm can improve the N2 selectivity of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst. Finally, the introduction of Sm species to the 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst promoted the SCR activity and N2 selectivity at the temperature range of 80−300 °C and broadened the active temperature window. 3.2 Physicochemical properties of Mn-Sm/Ti catalysts The morphologies and element distribution of 20 Mn/TiO2 and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalysts were illustrated in Fig. 2 . The SEM images revealed that the 20 Mn/TiO2 and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalysts both presented rough morphologies with porous structure. Furthermore, the element mappings demonstrated that the Mn on the surface of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst was distributed more uniformly than that on 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst, indicating that the addition of Sm promoted the distribution of Mn on the TiO2 support. Besides, the Sm was uniformly doped onto the surface of the support. Table 1 shows the specific surface areas of Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts. The BET surface areas of Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts decreased compared to that of TiO2 support. Generally, the surface area of catalyst decreases after introduction of active metal due to the pore blocking of the TiO2 support. However, the surface areas of Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts increased with an increase in Sm loading, in which the 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst possessed largest surface area. These indicate that the doped Sm could promote the dispersion of manganese oxide on the surface of TiO2 support as the introduction of Sm can restrain the crystallization of MnO x [25]. The excess amount of Sm addition could give rise to a decrease in the surface area of 20 Mn-20Sm/TiO2 catalyst. The variation in surface areas of Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts was in good agreement with the results of catalytic performance measurement. The XRD patterns of Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . The diffraction peaks of anatase TiO2 (JCPDS #21-1272) and rutile TiO2 (JCPDS #21-1276) corresponding to Degussa P25 TiO2 (80 % anatase and 20 % rutile) were observed for all the Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts. The diffraction peaks of Mn and Sm species could not be detected, which clearly indicated that the Mn and Sm species were highly dispersed and/or amorphous. After Mn species were deposited on TiO2 support, the intensities of TiO2 diffraction peaks significantly decreased. Besides, an increase in Sm content in Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts further decreases the intensities of TiO2 diffraction peaks. These verified that there were strong interaction between Mn and Sm species and TiO2 support. The crystal structure of these catalysts was further characterized by Raman spectra and the corresponding results are displayed in Fig. 4 . It is observed that all the catalysts exhibit four obvious Raman bands at ca. 143, 395, 518, 638 cm−1, which are ascribed to the Eg(1), B1g(1), A1g + B1g(2), and Eg(2) vibration modes of anatase TiO2, respectively [28,29]. Compared to 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst, the Raman bands of anatase TiO2 in Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts with Sm loading shifted due to interaction between Sm and Ti. No Raman bands of Mn and Sm species appeared in 20 Mn/TiO2, 20 Mn-5Sm/TiO2 and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalysts, revealing that Mn and Sm species are highly dispersed on the surface of these catalysts, which is in accordance with the results of XRD. However, a weak Raman band at 583 cm−1 is observed in 20 Mn-20Sm/TiO2 catalyst, which is assigned to MnO2 [30,31]. This denotes the low MnO2 dispersion resulting from excessive loading of Sm on the surface of 20 Mn-20Sm/TiO2 catalyst, which is in agreement with BET results described above. In order to obtain the information about oxidation state and surface atomic concentrations of Ti, Sm, Mn and O, the XPS spectra of 20 Mn/TiO2 and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalysts were recorded, and shown in Fig. 5 . These two catalysts possess two main peaks of Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 located at ∼464.4 and ∼458.6 eV, respectively, which are ascribed to characteristic peak of Ti4+ species. However, the binding energies of Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 peaks of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst shift slightly to low binding energy direction compared to that of 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst, indicating that there are electron interaction between Ti and Sm. The two main peaks of Sm 3d5/2 and Sm 3d3/2 centered at 1083.2 and 1110.3 eV are assigned to Sm3+ species [32], indicating that the Sm2O3 exists in the 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst. The two main peaks of Mn 2p located at ∼642.1 and ∼653.7 eV due to spin–orbit splitting were attributed to Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2, respectively. To identify the Mn phases and relative content of Mn species, the overlapped Mn 2p peaks were deconvoluted to three peaks by Gaussian-Lorentz fitting. The peaks at ∼641.2, ∼642.4, and ∼644.3 eV are ascribed to Mn3+, Mn4+, and Mn2+, respectively [10,12,19]. The relative contents of Mn, O species were calculated by the area ratio of the corresponding characteristic peaks, which are summarized in Table 2 . The relative atomic concentrations ratio of Mn4+/Mn3+ increased from 2.08 for 20 Mn/TiO2 to 2.46 for 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2. The introduction of Sm results in the increase of Mn4+ species on the surface of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2. Kapteijn et al. [33] found that MnO2 exhibits the highest SCR activity in the MnO x species at low temperature. The excellent catalytic activity of MnO2 is due to its lattice defects [34]. Therefore, the low-temperature SCR activity of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst could be enhanced compared to 20 Mn/TiO2, which is agreement with the results of activity measurement. Besides, the XPS results on surface atomic ratio of Mn/Ti showed a significant change (Table 2). The surface relative atomic concentration of Mn was increased after the introduction of Sm. This indicates that the presence of Sm could inhibit the crystallization of manganese oxide through the possible formation of Mn-O-Sm bonds and promote the surface dispersion of Mn on the support through incorporation of Mn into the vacant site of TiO2 lattice. This is beneficial for SCR activity of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst. The O 1s XPS spectra of the Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts was shown in Fig. 5. The O 1s peaks could be fitted with two peaks for each sample. The sub-bands located at ∼529.9 and ∼531.6 eV were ascribed to lattice oxygen (denoted as Oβ) and surface chemisorbed oxygen (denoted as Oα), respectively [35,36]. The ratio of Oα/Oβ was obviously increased from 0.44 for 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst to 0.86 for 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst (Table 2), suggesting that the addition of Sm significantly promotes the surface active oxygen species. The Oα/Oβ ratio of Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalyst is higher than that of Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalyst in our previous work [37] because the preparation method was improved. It is generally accepted that Oα is more active than Oβ as a result of its relatively higher mobility and lower energy bonding to the surface [6,36,38]. In the SCR reactions, the adsorbed NH3 could be activated to NH2 by dehydrogenation which is favored by the surface oxygen (Oα). This process was demonstrated by the in situ DRIFTS results mentioned below. The high concentrations of MnO2 and surface oxygen (Oα) on the surface are beneficial to the catalytic activity of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst for the NH3-SCR of NO x . 3.3 NH3-TPD The NH3-TPD is often used to evaluate the surface acidity of catalyst. Fig. 6 shows the NH3-TPD curves of the Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts. The peaks located at temperatures below 250 °C are ascribed to NH3 desorbed from weak acid sites, while that above 250 °C are attributed to NH3 desorbed from strong acid sites. The TPD profiles of all the catalysts contained both weak and strong adsorption peaks. It has been confirmed that NH3 adsorbed on weak acid sites can participate in the SCR reactions at low temperatures, while NH3 adsorbed on strong acid sites is not involved in low temperature SCR process [39]. Compared to 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst, the amount of weak acid sites of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst increased after Sm doping. These indicates that more NH3 adsorbed on the surface of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst can take part in the low-temperature SCR reaction compared to that on the surface of 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst, which would increase the NO conversion of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst. Besides, the content of weak acid sites of 20 Mn-20Sm/TiO2 catalysts are significantly decreased due to small surface area and excessive Sm species covered part of active sites. The amount of weak acid sites reflected by the TPD curves decreases in the order 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 > 20 Mn/TiO2 > 20 Mn-20Sm/TiO2, which follows the trend in catalytic activity: 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 > 20 Mn/TiO2 > 20 Mn-20Sm/TiO2, suggesting that weak acid site is an important factor that governs catalytic activity. 3.4 H2-TPR To evaluate the reducibility of the Mn-Sm/TiO2 catalysts, the H2-TPR experiments were carried out for these catalysts. Fig. 7 gives the H2-TPR profiles. A two-step reduction curves were observed for all the catalysts. The first peak represents the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 and the second peak could be due to the reduction of subsequent Mn2O3 to MnO [6,10,40]. The low-temperature reduction peak of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 and onset temperature of reduction shifted to comparatively lower temperature in the presence of Sm compared to 20 Mn/TiO2 due to the interaction between Mn and Sm, indicating that the redox property of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst was enhanced. The enhanced reducibility of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst is beneficial for the activation of adsorbed reactant to form important initial intermediates. 3.5 In situ DRIFTS investigations 3.5.1 Adsorption and desorption of NH3 To further investigate the types of surface acid sites of the catalysts, the in situ NH3 adsorption and desorption experiments were carried out and the corresponding results are given in Fig. 8 . After adsorption of NH3 over 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst, only one obvious band at 1540 cm−1 appeared in the DRIFT spectra. The band is ascribed to -NH2 species generated by dehydrogenation from NH3 coordinately linked to Lewis acid sites [5,41]. This indicates that there are mainly Lewis acid sites on the surface of 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst. This band gradually disappeared with the increase of temperature. For the 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst, five bands at 1595, 1558, 1540, 1428 and 1347 cm-1 were observed after NH3 adsorption. The band at 1595 cm−1 belongs to NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [5,42]. The bands at 1558 and 1347 cm−1 are assigned to -NH2 species bound to Lewis acid sites [20,28,43,44]. And the last band at 1428 cm−1 is attributed to NH4 + linked to Brønsted acid sites [5]. The amount of Lewis acid sites was much more than that of Brønsted acid sites on the surface of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst. The bands related to NH3 and –NH2 species almost disappeared and band of NH4 + species still existed after the temperature rose to 200 °C. Combined with results of NH3-TPD, the weak acid sites on the catalysts mainly refer to Lewis acid sites. 3.5.2 Reaction of NH3 with pre-adsorbed NO + O2 In situ DRIFT spectra of Mn/TiO2 and Mn-Sm/TiO2 in flowing NH3/N2 at different times after adsorption of NO + O2/N2 are shown in Fig. 9 . As displayed in Fig. 9a, after adsorption of NO + O2, the bands at 1606, 1584, 1532, and 1273 cm−1 were observed. The band at 1606 cm-1 is ascribed to bridging nitrate [41,42]. The bands at 1584, 1532, and 1273 cm-1 are all assigned to bidentate nitrate [20,38,45]. After the adsorption of NO + O2, the catalyst was subsequently treated in the flow of NH3. It was observed that the bands at 1606 cm−1 were gradually decreased with an increase in flow time of NH3 and finally disappeared after exposure to NH3 for 6 min. The bands at 1584, 1532, 1273 cm-1 gradually shifted to 1568, 1525, 1285 cm-1, respectively, with an increase in exposure time of NH3, which are all attributed to bidentate nitrate [5,25,38,41,46] and their intensities were almost unchanged. The shift may be due to the presence of NH3. The new bands at 1500, 1196, 1166 cm-1 appeared after 6 min of flowing NH3. The bands at 1196 and 1166 cm-1 are assigned to corresponding bending vibrations [2,5,42,47]. The band at 1500 cm-1 is due to the oxidation/deformation of adsorbed NH3 [47]. These results indicates that bridging nitrates are the main active nitrate species on the surface of Mn/TiO2 catalyst, which can take part in SCR reactions. After the consumption of these nitrate species, more NH3 could adsorb on the surface acid sites and then the adsorption bands of NH3 were appeared. It can be concluded that the SCR reactions over the Mn/TiO2 catalyst can proceed through Langmuir−Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism. In situ DRIFT spectra of the 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst are presented in Fig. 9b. After the adsorption of NO + O2, the bands at 1553 and 1267 cm−1 appeared, which are ascribed to bidentate nitrate [5,45]. Subsequently, the NO/O2 preadsorbed catalyst was treated in NH3/N2 flow. The bands at 1553 and 1267 cm−1 shifted to 1532 and 1276 cm−1, respectively, which were also assigned to bidentate nitrate. The bridging nitrates were not formed on the surface of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst. Interestingly, the intensities of bidentate nitrates over the 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst were hardly changed with an increase in exposure time of NH3, indicating that these nitrate species were stable against NH3 attack and covered the adsorption sites on the surface of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst, which could inhibit the adsorption of NH3 on the surface. Therefore, only a weak band at 1195 cm−1 corresponding to coordinated NH3 bound to Lewis acid sites was appeared under NH3/N2 flow, which resulted in the shift of the bands related to the preadsorbed nitrates. These indicated that the SCR reactions over 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst could not happen via Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. 3.5.3 Reaction of NO + O2 with pre-adsorbed NH3 In situ DRIFT spectra of 20 Mn/TiO2 and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalysts with preadsorbed NH3 exposure to NO + O2 are shown in Fig. 10 . As observed in Fig. 10a, after adsorption of NH3, the same bands appeared for 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst was observed after exposure to NO/O2 and following by NH3/N2 flow. The bands at 3384, 3337, 3254, 1196, and 1161 cm−1 are attributed to NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [42]. The new bands are due to NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (3017 cm−1) [41], coordinated NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites (1596 and 1305 cm−1) [42], and wagging mode of -NH2 (1342 cm−1) [20]. Upon subsequent exposure of the NH3-pretreated catalyst to a flow of NO + O2, all bands of coordinated NH3, NH4 + and -NH2 species disappeared gradually after exposure to NO + O2 for 14 min and bands already known for adsorbed nitrates arose. The band at 1606 cm−1 is ascribed to bridging nitrate, and the bands at 1583, 1530, 1267 cm−1 are assigned to bidentate nitrate. It is noted that the band at 1196 cm−1 attributed to nitrite species [5] increased initially and then decreased with an increase in flow time and finally disappeared after 90 min of NO + O2 flow while the intensities of nitrates increased distinctly, indicating that the nitrite species can be slowly oxidized to nitrate species. The in situ DRIFT spectra of 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst after flowing NO + O2 for 90 min are in agreement with that of 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst after adsorption of NO + O2 (Fig. 9a). As shown in Fig. 10b, the bands at 3388, 3255, 1587, 1560, 1428, 1360, 1159, 1122, 1104 cm−1 are obtained. The bands at 3388, 3255, 1159 cm-1 are due to coordinated NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites. The new bands are attributed to coordinated NH3 bound to the Lewis acid sites (1587 and 1122 cm-1) [25,47–50], -NH2 species formed by dehydrogenation from NH3 coordinately linked to Lewis acid sites (1560, 1540, 1523, 1505, 1360 cm-1) [5,28,44,51], protonated ammonia adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites (1428 cm-1) [5], hydrogen-nitrogen bonds (1104 cm-1) [42,52]. After adsorption of NH3, the flow of NH3 was replaced by NO + O2. The bands of NH3 ad-species almost vanished after exposure to NO + O2 for 2 min while the nitrite and nitrate species appeared. The same phenomenon is observed for the variations of in situ DRIFT spectra of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst. The bands at 1420 and 1193 cm-1 ascribed to monodentate nitrite [53] and nitrite species [5], respectively, increased initially and then decreased with an increase in exposure time as a result of the further oxidation to bidentate nitrate, and finally vanished after 90 min in the flow of NO + O2. The bands at 1557, 1267, 1019 cm-1 are assigned to bidentate nitrate [38]. When the adsorption time approached 120 min, the DRIFT spectra of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst are similar to that of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst after adsorption of NO + O2 in Fig. 9b. It is observed that the reaction of preadsorbed NH3 with NO + O2 on the surface of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst was significantly faster than that over 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst. It is obvious that the Sm modified catalyst possessed more –NH2 species than 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst and the amide species (–NH2) quickly disappeared in NO + O2 flow. The –NH2 specie is the key intermediate in SCR reaction at low temperature formed by hydrogen abstraction from coordinated ammonia, which is facilitated by reactive surface oxygen (Oα) [6,40,41]. This indicates that the Sm modified catalyst possess stronger redox property, which is accordance with the results of XPS and H2-TPR. 3.5.4 Adsorption and reaction of NH3 + NO + O2 The in situ DRIFT spectra of adsorption species on 20 Mn/TiO2 and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalysts in the atmosphere of NO + NH3 + O2 are recorded. As shown in Fig. 11 a, the bands at 3338, 3252, 1600, 1292, 1151 cm−1 are ascribed to NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [5,28,42] and the band at 1261 cm-1 may be assigned to the oxidization/deformation species of adsorbed ammonia [46]. The bands at 1559 and 1541 cm−1 are attributed to bidentate nitrate [38,42] while the band at 1485 cm−1 is due to monodentate nitrate [54]. The band at 1204 cm−1 is ascribed to nitrite species [5] and its intensity gradually decreased with an increase in adsorption time, indicating the oxidation of nitrite to nitrate species. The co-existence of the NH3 ad-species and NO x ad-species on the surface of 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst are observed under SCR steady-state reaction. However, the reactive bridging nitrate appeared in the adsorption experiment of NO + O2 and the –NH2 with NH4 + intermediates appeared in NH3 adsorption experiment are all absent in the SCR steady-state reaction, suggesting that the active intermediates could be quickly consumed through the reactions between NH4 +/–NH2 species and bridging nitrate/gaseous NO. As shown in Fig. 11b, only five bands appeared in SCR reaction over 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst. The bands at 3376, 3277, 1595, and 1192 cm−1 are attributed to coordinated NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites according to above analysis. The new band at 1415 cm−1 is ascribed to bending vibrations of NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites. The phenomena differing most from the transient reactions is the absence of NO x ad-species and –NH2 species. Considering the sharp peaks of nitrate species in the transient reaction experiments and the absence of nitrite/nitrate species in steady-state reaction, one can conclude that the adsorption of NO could not happen in the presence of NH3 due to competitive adsorption between NH3 and NO. The large amount of NH2 species in the NH3 adsorption experiment and the absence of these species in SCR steady-state reaction indicate that the formed –NH2 species quickly reacted with gaseous NO to produce N2 and H2O. 3.6 H2O and SO2 resistance of the catalysts 3.6.1 Effect of H2O and SO2 on NO x conversion The resistance to H2O and SO2 is important for low-temperature SCR catalyst. The H2O and SO2 tolerance tests were performed over 20 Mn/TiO2 and 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalysts at 200 °C with simulated flue gas including H2O and SO2. Fig. 12 shows the influence of H2O and SO2 on the catalytic performance of the two catalysts. For the 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst, the NO x conversion remained unchanged after the introduction of 5 vol.% H2O for 2 h. Subsequently, 100 ppm of SO2 was added to the feed gas, the NO x conversion decreased from 82 to 70 % after exposure to SO2 for 2 h and could not fully recover after cutting off SO2. Then, the NO x conversion gradually decreased from 80 to 21 % after simultaneous introduction of H2O and SO2 for 12 h. After the H2O and SO2 were removed from feed gas, the NO x conversion could not recover. For the 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst, the introduction of H2O resulted in unchange in NO x conversion. While, the individual SO2 also had a negative influence on NO x conversion. Afterwards, both H2O and SO2 were injected into the feed gas, the NO x conversion decreased from 89 to 52 % after 12 h, which shows that the deactivation rate of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst is slower than that of 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst. After removing the H2O and SO2 from feed gas, the NO x conversion recovered slightly. The results of the above experiments indicate that 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst exhibits better H2O and SO2 resistance than 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst. H2O has nearly no influence on the SCR reaction, while SO2 has a remarkable poisoning effect on the catalysts. One possible reason is that there exists a competitive adsorption between SO2 and NH3, which was demonstrated by our previous research [37]. However, the main reason may be that the SO2 reacted with NH3 and/or surface metal oxides of the catalyst to form sulfates, which covered the active sites and gave rise to the irreversible deactivation, as the catalytic performance could not recover after removing the H2O and SO2. Therefore, the surface sulfates formed on the catalysts should be further analyzed. 3.6.2 TG-DSC-MS analysis of the catalysts The TG-DSC-MS experiments were carried out for the above spent and fresh catalysts to get deeply insight into the deactivation reason of the catalysts. Associating weight loss with the SO2 release, the weight loss of fresh catalyst was subtracted from the weight loss of spent catalyst and the corresponding results are displayed in Fig. 13 . The release of SO2 was detected for both two catalysts at the temperature range of 700−900 °C, indicating the decomposition of the surface sulfates. Besides, the TG curves and endothermic peaks of DSC curves at this temperature range can also prove the decomposition of sulfate species. Considering the decomposition temperature, the surface sulfates are ascribed to MnSO4 and/or Sm2(SO4)3 because these sulfate species could decompose at the temperature range [27,40]. The peak intensity of SO2 of 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst is higher than that of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst. Furthermore, it can be seen that the peak area of SO2 released from 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst is also larger than that of SO2 from 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst, indicating that the amount of metal sulfates formed on the 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst is more than that on the 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst. Besides, the surface S content of the spent catalysts was further analyzed by XPS and the corresponding results are listed in Table 3 . It can be seen that the S content of spent 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst was less than that of spent 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst, which is in accordance with the result of TG-MS. Therefore, it can be concluded that the Sm doping can inhibit the formation of metal sulfate on the surface of the 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst for the existence of Sm could suppress the oxidation of SO2 to SO3 [26]. 3.7 Discussion For 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst, the reaction between pre-adsorbed nitrate with NH3 and NH3 ad-species with gaseous NO can both proceed. Additionally, both the NH3 and NO x ad-species appeared and the key intermediates vanished on the surface of 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst in SCR atmosphere. These indicates that both Langmuir-Hinshelwood (bridging nitrate is the active intermediate) and Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism are working for the SCR reaction on the 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst. For 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst, the presence of Sm prevents the formation of bridging nitrate and the pre-adsorbed bidentate nitrate could not react with NH3 while the rapid reaction between the pre-adsorbed NH3 species and gaseous NO was achieved in transient SCR reaction. Furthermore, it is interesting that NO x ad-species and –NH2 species vanished, leaving only NH3 and NH4 + species appearing on the surface of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst in the SCR steady-state reaction, indicating that the introduction of Sm can prevent the adsorption of NO in the presence of NH3. Considering these, it can be concluded that the SCR reaction over 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst proceeds only via the Eley-Rideal mechanism, in which the –NH2 species is the crucial active intermediate. The breaking of NH bond during the formation or decomposition of the intermediates in SCR reactions is the rate-determining step [55]. The higher amount of –NH2 species formed on the surface of Sm modified catalyst and the quicker vanishing of these species indicate that the NH bonds are easy to break in the presence of Sm. Therefore, the addition of Sm can significantly promote the catalytic activity for SCR reactions at low temperature. The SCR reaction over 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst also follows Mars–van Krevelen mechanism [2,55,56], where the NH3 react with surface oxygen associated with surface manganese sites to form NH2 species and then the NH2 react with gaseous NO to produce N2 and H2O, and the reduced surface manganese site is subsequently reoxidized by gaseous O2. However, there exists a competitive adsorption between SO2 and NH3. And the doping of Sm could suppress the formation of metal sulfate. The SCR reaction over 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst at low temperature can be described in Scheme 1 . In the previous studies, Meng et al. [25] found that the presence of Sm can restrain the crystallization of MnO x and increase its surface area and the relative content of Mn4+ and Oα, and SCR reaction over Sm-MnO x catalyst follows both L-H and E-R mechanisms, in which the E-R mechanism is predominant. Gao et al. [57] studied Sm-modified MnO x -TiO2 catalysts prepared by an inverse co-precipitation method, which showed good NO x conversion due to the increase in surface area, chemisorbed oxygen and surface acid sites. However, the surface concentration of Mn4+ decreased after introduction of Sm, promoting the N2 selectivity at high temperature. Furthermore, the SCR reaction over this catalyst can proceed via both L-H and E-R mechanisms at low temperature. In this work, we can demonstrate that the doping of Sm improves the surface properties of Mn/TiO2 catalyst by increasing Mn4+ and surface chemisorption oxygen as well as weak acid sites. However, the effect of Sm on the surface content of Mn4+ is discordant in these studies. Moreover, SCR reaction mechanisms over Sm-modified Mn-based catalysts are obviously different because the SCR reaction over 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst follows only E-R mechanism at low temperature. In addition, we found that the presence of Sm promotes the resistance to SO2 of Mn/TiO2 catalyst. Sun et al. [26] suggested that the oxidation of SO2 may be suppressed by electron transfer between Sm and Mn ions, which inhibited the formation of sulfate. The catalyst component, content of active species and preparation method all affect the catalytic activity of Sm-modified catalyst. Getting deeper insight into the interaction between Sm and Mn is still needed, which is beneficial for designing the Sm-modified Mn-based low-temperature SCR catalyst. 4 Conclusions The Sm modified Mn/TiO2 catalyst is proposed for catalytic reduction of gas-phase NO at low temperature. The best 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst achieved over 80 % NO x conversion at the temperature range of 110−250 °C with a gas hourly space velocity of 80,000 h−1. The presence of Sm could improve the dispersion of manganese oxide on the surface of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst and increase its surface area as well as the amount of weak Lewis acid sites. The relative concentration of surface oxygen (Oα) is also increased after introduction of Sm, which enhances the redox property of 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst. The SCR reaction on 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst follows both Eley-Rideal and Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism (bridging nitrate is the active intermediate). For 20 Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst, the SCR reaction mechanism changes by inhibiting the adsorption of NO in the presence of Sm and the reactions proceed only through Eley-Rideal mechanism, in which –NH2 species is the key intermediate. Moreover, the SCR reaction involves a Mars–van Krevelen redox cycle, where easier breaking of NH bond after introduction of Sm boost the reaction rate. The Sm doping decreases the formation rate of metal sulfate on the surface of 20 Mn/TiO2 catalyst. CRediT authorship contribution statement Lijun Liu: Writing - original draft. coredata.dc:description: A series of Sm modified Mn/TiO2 catalysts were proposed for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 and their catalytic activity was evaluated at low temperature. The effect of Sm on the catalytic activity of Mn-Sm/TiO2 was comprehensively studied using XRD, low-temperature N2 adsorption, XPS, NH3-TPD and H2-TPR. The results showed that the 20Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst, prepared by ultrasonic impregnation, exhibited NO x conversion of higher than 80 % at the temperature range of 110–250 °C with a gas hourly space velocity of 80,000 h−1. The weak Lewis acid site and redox ability may be crucial properties for catalytic performance as a result of the increase of Mn4+ and surface chemisorption oxygen as well as weak acid sites due to the enhanced interaction among Mn, Sm and Ti after addition of Sm. The in situ DRIFTS experiments were conducted to investigate the adsorption of NH3 and NO with their surface reaction. The results revealed that the SCR reactions on the surface of Mn/TiO2 catalyst follow both Langmuir-Hinshelwood and Eley-Rideal mechanism and bridging nitrate is the important intermediate. While, that on surface of 20Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst comply with only Eley-Rideal mechanism, as the introduction of Sm changes the reaction path by inhibiting the adsorption of NO in the presence of NH3. Besides, SCR reaction rate over 20Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst is fast as a result of large amount of -NH2 species formed on the surface of 20Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst for the breaking of NH bonds become easier over the Sm modified catalyst, which is beneficial for SCR activity of 20Mn-10Sm/TiO2 catalyst at low temperature. The TG-DSC-MS results revealed that the addition of Sm reduce the sulfation of Mn/TiO2 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient Sm modified Mn/TiO2 catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 at low temperature
